    ### Task Description ###

    For each target, determine the stance in the comment:
    - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR
    - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST
    - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE
    - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED

    ### KEY CLAIM ###
    - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance
    - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: <extracted claim>".
    - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. 

    ### Output Format: ###

    You must output only JSON format:
    {
      "results": [
        {
          "target": "<original_target>", 
          "stance": "<one among [FAVOR, AGAINST, NONE, NOT RELATED]>", 
          "stance_type": "<one among [EXPLICIT, IMPLICIT, NONE]>",
          "explanation": "<I agree with the following: ...> if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST"
        },
        // Repeat for each target
      ]
    }
    
    ONLY return the JSON object itself.

# News comment title:
Who is the Most Reviled Person in America?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This is what should have happened from the beginning.   The Head of the IRS and Obama aren't monitoring people on that level so they would not have had anything to do with this situation.  This happened on the department level and should be dealt with there. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
This is how you do it:

1.  Cut funding for an agency and make the law that they administer more complex.

2.  Flood them with complicated work.

3.  Then complain that you are NOT  being treated fairly.

4.  Get the MSM, VSPs,  and even some some left-center bloggers(who shall be unnamed) to agree.  "This is so unfair!!"

4.  Pick on the little guys at the agency who have to mortgage their homes to pay for legal advice.  They will cooperate with you.

5.  $$-- !!SUCCESS!!-- $$  Anonymous political funding for right-wing  groups is beyond reproach.  And we have a White House "scandal" to boot to gin up the Krazy Base.   Koch Bros. and Rove uncork the champagne.
 
Very nicely done!

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I'm kinda wondering, was the tea party name copyrighted or in some way kept off left wing references for 501s?

Besides, I don't consider "tea party" to be a right wing meme, unless the right wing really wants to claim a bunch of idiots.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

The argument put forward by the deranged Tea Party (I know, redundant) types is that because his mother was an American citizen Cruz is thus "naturalized" and eligible. Benghazi is now synonymous with conservative political theatre.  Instead of actually putting forward a viable candidate for President, the GOP's plan is to fling as much mud as possible to sling at any possible Democratic candidates.  One of these years, they will need to come up with a platform of ideas and solutions, but I do not see that any time soon.

# News comment title:
Climate Change is Already Here, and It's Not Pretty

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I'm tired of all the promises the climate experts keep making.  They keep saying it's going to warm up and it never does.  I froze my a** off this winter and the spring has been freezing.  I keep hoping they are right and it will get warmer, but it never does.  I'm starting to think they are making this stuff up.

Carry on..

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
We didn't get that memo because the 10 hottest years on record are all recent. You got that memo because idiots get special news. Adjust the chin strap on your padded helmet. Don't chew your crayons. Good boy.

# News comment title:
Fine. I Retract My Defense of Optics.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
As Kevin's readers are aware, I'm no wordsmith--hence I won't comment on the lexicon issue. I can, however, report with confidence that the wingnuts aren't talking so much about the photograph anymore as they are instead nominating Bernadette (Bernadette Lancelin, the Houston woman Fox interviewed earlier this week, who delivered a profanity-laced rant to the camera about her opposition to helping the border children) for the GOP Presidential ticket in 2016.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I recall the initial outrage over Bush's response to Katrina being that he didn't even think any FEMA involvement would be needed at all until five days after the storm hit, while it was obvious in a day or two that it was a disaster. It was Republican ideology that made him think Louisiana should go it alone.


The flip side to the bizarre Presidential action meme is that, not only is there always something going on in the world, it seems to assume that if the President is not personally on the scene, then nothing is being done. Of course trying to portray Obama as a do-nothing President is a perfect fit with the racist stereotype of a lazy black man, which is part of why I suspect they constantly bang on that drum. But even if you factor out that racist tinge entirely, there is some kind of bizarre GOP fantasy involved that assumes a President should be some kind of Rambo Action Hero, ala Bush's Mission Accomplished photo-op. Perhaps this explains their Putin fantasies, because he appears barechested on horseback, which has the smell of Reaganesque manliness.


But actually a competent President with good cabinet heads should be able to handle immediate response to a crisis from anywhere with phone calls, especially for example a situation like Benghazi where military command is already authorized to respond defensively to direct attacks on US personnel stationed abroad without consulting the President. How silly to think that when Americans are fired upon they should wait until they hear from the President before doing anything. The idea that the President should be watching on video and giving commands in real time during an attack like that is a TV fantasy worthy of a Jack Bauer "24" fiction. 


On the Border crisis he has already put plans in place, mobilized personnel and resources, given directives, etc. To expect that he personally should be busy around the clock with whatever the 24-hour news cycle is obsessed with is completely laughable.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Any opportunity on the right to call Obama "uppity" without actually using those words will be beaten like a dead horse.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Is This the Most Astonishing Obamacare Result Ever?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
As a long-time hospital employee and medical economics & finance professional, I can tell you that the change is absolutely due to ACA, and I am as amazed as anybody how broad-based that shift has been by the industry.  Not only does ACA impose (initially modest) financial penalties, but it creates a competitive, reputational incentive that's just as powerful. Prior to ACA, hospitals either didn't devote resources to reducing readmissions, or had those resources stymied by countervailing interests, such as the potential loss of revenue and the resistance to change in work processes by doctors and nurses. Most fundamentally, the change required is one in mindset--rather than just managing a particular event--the index admission--you have to think about an individual patient's needs over time and across the care "continuum"--home, hospital, doctor's office, nursing home, etc.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

"Before then, the status quo was simple: [people who look like] men used one bathroom and [people who look like] women used another." Fify.

No body went looking in someone's underwear to see if the anatomy matched the perception.  And why should they? # News comment title:
How Good Is Flint's Water These Days?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Looks like we need more data.  
Curious about the haphazard installation of filters though. Maybe they should do inspections to check for compliance.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"3. City Council of Flint, their mayor, and city's emergency manager (appointed by the state), decided to leave Detroit and get water from a nearby source. Local construction companies and the water utility were all excited and the "stimulus" construction would provide for Flint.
Democrats, Rachel Maddow and others have desperately pined the mess solely on Michigan's Republican governor, he's one of many culpable, but not alone. Documents abound show the city council was in favor of this plan, as was the mayor."

Truthiness in action. The mayor and city council had NO power to veto the deal; the city was controlled by the emergency manager appointed by the state. Reps, especially Alex Jones, have tried to obscure this point for years.
 
"5. Flint switched their water supply to the Flint River. The engineering firm brought in to consult strongly advised them to treat the water for Ph level, and Flint's own water utility has documentation that they heard and received this advice, but nobody did.
6. Residents started complaining about the water to city officials. No one did anything."

Nobody and no one being the emergency manager. See above.

"8. Activists got university officials to come test the water, and it failed. The governor was notified, and finally the state government got into action.
All levels of government in Michigan are culpable in this disaster. Democrats trying to pin this solely on Rick Snyder are misleading you. He should be in trouble for this, but so should many others."

Plenty of blame to go around, yes, but the buck stops somewhere, and Snyder's efforts to avoid any culpability have been pretty pathetic. It's like the guy whose kids stole your car blaming you for leaving a door unlocked.

# News comment title:
Business Community Shocked That Trump Might Impose Import Tariffs

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Your joy is kind overlooking the fact that corps are filled with middle income people who will be impacted as much or more. Consequences of a trade war won't be isolated to one economic class, including probably most of the posters here in one way or another 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Regardless of what Wilbur Ross thinks, it is unlikely that Paul Ryan or Mitch McConnell will let a 5% tariff go through.  They claim to favor free trade, and much of their donations come from the business community that benefits from this free trade.

That said, there will be a lot of pain felt by working class whites based on Trump's polices (or lack thereof).  Many regulations designed to protect consumers and the environment will affect working class people the most if they are rolled back as expected.  Expected oil spikes will bring back inflationary cycles which also hurt working class the most as wages always lag behind rising prices.  And ultimately we are looking at a recession with Trump as interest rates rise precipitously to slow inflation, putting a lot of people out of work, most of which will be working class.  

The only issue I see is timing.  How fast and how far will America fall under Trump?  Will he be able to put off most of the pain until after the 2018 election; and if he does that, what position will that put the Republicans in 2020 with a down economy?  Like Reagan, I imagine Trump will try to distract the American people with war and terrorism, but when you are out of work and losing your home, I am not sure if anti-Muslim and anti-minority vitriol is going to save Trump and the Republicans in 2020, assuming they are able to avoid mass American economic pain before the 2018 elections.

# News comment title:
Obama Was Right Not to Get Involved in Syria

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The situation is actually more complex than Kevin describes. Obama's critics seem to think he should have found a way to bring down the Assad regime AND destroy ISIS. There was, and is, simply no plausible way of achieving this even if the nation had been behind him in both objectives. The opposite was true, of course; the president-elect and a large chunk of the majority party in Congress believe Russia should be congratulated for what it's achieved and implicitly support the Assad regime.

The president's errors have been rhetorical, not substantive. Viewed objectively, Russia is struggling to sustain a regime which is its only ally in the region, while the US (appears to be) making steady progress in winding back ISIS' territorial gains and weakening its fighting strength. Most importantly, Obama has not supported any of the rival groups unconditionally and has thereby avoided becoming hostage to any of them in the way that's unfortunately been typical of American interventions in other complex regional conflicts.

# News comment title:
In the Future, Will We All Be Geniuses?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Hey, maybe the Republicans just succeed in their efforts to kill off everyone who is poor.

Oh, and it would have to turn out that their "poverty equals stupid equals immoral" is true...so...um...never mind.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
All I can say is that the average IQ will still be 100, because that's the definition of the average IQ.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Implying that Ben Carson has a high IQ, because he certainly seems stupid to me?  Perhaps people conflate an ability to repeat intricate tasks with high IQ, something manufacturing automation seems quite capable of doing without seemingly possessing high IQ.

Never have I felt we characterize IQ differently than reality then when my dog occasionally sits in front of me and seemingly lectures me on something I cannot divine, forcing me to ponder whether the dog is smarter than my MENSA category might suggest.  Just as she is handicapped by a lack of an opposing thumb, so, to, am I handicapped by a lack of sense of smell, compared to her. (She went through three "trainers", after about thirty minutes of work she would get bored and each "trainer" would give up and leave, laughing hysterically after, each time, we caught the dog in a corner of the field, practicing, in the order she was taught, each maneuver.)

Humans, with few exceptions, are "blind" so some 70,000 different smells, crippling our perceptions of reality.  Trump's Cabinet meeting yesterday is prime point at how smelling Trump's feeble attempt at master-bation would have informed the membership's sense of reality and would have indicated a sense of departure.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Elderly Are Probably Better Off Than We Think

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Given that the republicans are hell-bent on cutting health care benefits for older Americans, freezing funding for Meals on Wheels, cutting food stamps, and continuing with its social safety net shredding jihad that disproportionately impacts lower income Americans many of whom are older/elderly, I find it had to see how "the elderly" are "better than we think. In Trump's proposed 2018 budget.....

(1) The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program was trimmed. 
(2) Trump proposed killing the State Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP), which helps older adults navigate the complexities of Medicare and other insurance. 
(3) He’d eliminate the Labor Department’s $438 million Senior Community Service Employment Program, which helps older adults find jobs with local governments or non-profits. 

(4) He’d also cut funding for the National Institute on Aging (part of NIH) by $294 million, or more than 20 percent.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardgleckman/2017/05/23/trumps-budget-for-seniors-bad-but-it-could-have-been-worse/#379a2d837349
(5) Veterans Affairs Secretary Dr. David Shulkin defended Wednesday a proposal in President Donald Trump's federal budget plan that would cut a benefit paying thousands of dollars annually to disabled elderly veterans.... http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/05/24/elderly-vets-face-benefits-cut-trump-budget.html

(6) (With massive cuts to Medicaid) "...little has been said about what would happen to older Americans in nursing homes if the cuts took effect. Medicaid programs are required to cover nursing home care. But state officials decide how much to pay facilities, and states under budgetary pressure could decrease the amount they are willing to pay or restrict eligibility for coverage..... https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/24/science/medicaid-cutbacks-elderly-nursing-homes.html

Nobody can pay the grocer or the rent or the dentist with a chart.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Don't forget the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP).  Trump plans to freeze them out this winter.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I am currently busy with a senior in the high eighties using up her Medicare shuttling between a hospital and a "rehab" facility, using up her 100 days of paid healthcare in, well, 100 consecutive days, despite incurring various and sundry infections at rehab demanding she go to emergency.  My better half and myself spent almost every single day (and night) with her.  Most of other American patients were, for all intents and purposes, virtually abandoned by family and friends, much less than by the government.

As a Vietnam veteran, I am almost reduced to tears over the way we treat our elderly.  What, exactly, did we fight for?  This?  I visited many facilities, some with as many as five beds per room, mostly filled with real people with few or no visitors.  Even the North Vietnamese during the war treated their elders with more respect.

Absolutely disgusting that some Americans demand a profit from healthcare.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Oh Just Say It: Climate Change Is (Partly) Responsible For Houston’s Flooding

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
OK, just this once--this storm was more intense than traditionally expect because of global warming...

One thing that also needs to be pointed out--conditions that give rise to "100-year" flood (or 500, or...) may hang around for a few seasons, so clusters are sort of expected.  That said, if the the new conditions are now the new normal--then it's not the 500 year flood anymore...

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I live in Houston. My house is underwater and will be unlivable once I can return. While I don't disagree that climate change has a big impact on the storm, the 100/500 year storm estimates haven't been adjusted to all the building that's happened here in the past ten years. There are strip malls and large retail stores everywhere, each with an asphalt parking lot to hold thousands of cars. Much of the flooding is swell from upstream, areas that have also seen rapid population and development growth in recent years. Houston area has surpassed its ability to expand population and land use-wise. I don't think people are ready for that conversation yet. This may have been Houston's version of the Galveston 1900 hurricane.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


"But now, This is the first hurricane to hit the mainland US in 12 years.... "

I suppose in your book New Jersey is not the mainland, but nearly everyone thinks otherwise.  Hurricane Sandy.  2012.

>>> END COMMENT <<<
